STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 26, 2024
Cathey Prudhomme
Eagle Village, Inc.
4507 170TH Ave,
Hersey, MI, 49639-8785
Re: License #: CB670201101
Special Investigation #:2024C0000869SI
Dear Cathey Prudhomme:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB670201101
Special Investigation # 2024C0000869
Complaint Receipt Date 10/27/2023
Investigation Initiation Date 10/28/2023
Report due date 1/2/2024
Licensee Group Organization: Eagle Village Inc
Licensee Designee: Cathey Prudhomme
Chief Administrator: Cathey Prudhomme
Agency Name: Eagle Village Inc.
Agency Address: 4507 170TH AVE
HERSEY, MI 49639-8785
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 03/30/2025
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
10/27/2023 3:34 PM Email Special Investigation Initiation
10/28/2023 9:16 AM Email Document received: case name and
number
11/6/2023 3:17 PM Phone Telephone call to and from
complainant; Interview with
Complainant X.
11/6/2023 11:34 AM Email Document sent
RE: Special investigation
11/8/2023 4:28PM Email Document received
Email from Administrator 2 in reply to
my email to the Administrator 0
11/9/2023 4:23 PM Phone Other
Spoke with Administrator 2
1

11//13/2023 1:30 PM Video Conference Interview
11/13/2023 2 45 PM Video Conference Interview
11/17/2023 5:14 PM Phone Interview
11/21/2023 10:13 AM Phone Interview
12/5/2023 4:45PM Phone Interview
III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; Volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry.
Description (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The case worker gave false information in court related to the
caregiver asking a doctor to ask the birth mother to leave an
office visit for the child.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant X
On 11/6/2023 I interviewed Complainant X, a Department of
Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL) Analyst by telephone.
Complainant X reported that during a home visit with Caregiver
E, Caregiver E reported Worker 3, who is the Eagle Village
foster care worker for Child A, gave false testimony about her in
court. Caregiver E said, Worker 3 told the court she kicked
Parent C out of a doctor’s visit for Child A, which was not true.
Caregiver E reportedly showed a note from the doctor’s office
indicating it was the nurse not her who had asked Parent C to
leave the room. Complainant X reported Caregiver E stated she
did not believe she was given permission to supervise medical
appointments, but Worker 3 allowed Parent C to attend the
appointment without approval. Caregiver E did not report to
Complainant X whether Worker 3 had the aforementioned
doctor’s note nor whether Worker 3 had it at the time of Worker
3’s testimony in court.
Administrator 2
2

On 11/9/2023 I spoke with Administrator 2 about the allegations
by telephone. She reported Worker 3 and Supervisor 4 would
be best to address this allegation.
Worker 3 & Supervisor 4
On 11/13/2023 I interviewed Worker 3 and Supervisor 4
separately by video conference via TEAMs. Administrator 1 was
also present as a support person during each staff person’s
interview.
Worker 3 admitted there was an incident whereby Parent C
was not allowed in Child A’s doctor’s visit; and only Caregiver E
and Caregiver E’s daughter (who reportedly wants to adopt
Child A) were allowed to stay in the exam room. Worker 3
denied the allegations. She said she did not give false
information about the situation in court. She acknowledged
receiving a note from the child’s doctor’s office about the
medical visit. She said the doctor’s office only indicated they
only allow two people to be in the exam room. It was Caregiver
E who made the call about who stayed. That it was Caregiver E
who indicated to the doctor’s office which two people it would
be, her and her daughter. Worker 3 reported Parent C is
allowed to be aware of and to attend Child A’s medical
appointment. The court has not ordered against this.
Supervisor 4 reported Parent C and Grand Mother H go to all
of Child A’s medical appointments. During one visit, they were
asked to go wait in the waiting room while Caregiver E and
Caregiver E’s daughter met for Child A’s examination. Worker
3 had contacted the doctor’s office, and the doctor reported it
could only be two people. Supervisor 4 reported there was
concern Caregiver E may not have been encouraging Parent C
to be in the exam room. That when Worker 3 was reporting on
this situation in court Caregiver E became upset. Caregiver E
felt Worker 3 was trying to make it seem as though Caregiver E
had lied. Worker 3 was reporting to the court information she
had assessed about the situation. No false testimony was
given.
Caregiver E
I interviewed Caregiver E by telephone on 11/17/2023.
Caregiver E reported attending a court hearing via Zoom, at
which time Worker 3 told the court Caregiver E asked Parent C
to leave a doctor’s visit; but that never happened. Caregiver E
said Worker 3 reported Caregiver E should have advocated for
Parent C. Caregiver E said the doctor’s visit was on 7/7/2023,
3

and attended by her, her husband, her daughter, Parent C and
Grand Mother H. This was the first medical visit attended by
Parent C and Grand Mother H. Caregiver E said she thought
they all could go in the back for Child A’s medical visit; but a
nurse came in and told them only two people who care for the
child could come into the exam room. So, she and her daughter
went to the back for the exam. Caregiver E said she just
followed the nurse’s instructions. She denied telling Parent C
that Parent C could not come to the back with Child A for the
exam. Caregiver E did not say why her daughter was in
attendance at the visit or why she did not explain to the nurse it
would be okay for her and Parent C to go back for the exam.
Caregiver E reported due to Worker 3’s false information in
court about this matter, she obtained a letter from the doctor
showing it was the doctor not her who prevented Parent C from
coming to the exam room for that doctor’s visit. She emailed a
copy of the letter to the attorney.
Department Worker F and Guardian Ad Litem (GAL) G
Department Worker E and GAL G were interviewed by me via
telephone on 11/21/2023 and 12/5/2023 respectively.
Department Worker F admitted attending Child A’s court
hearings. She said she only vaguely recalled Worker 3
testifying in court that Caregiver E asked Parent C to leave a
medical visit. Department Worker F did not know whether
Worker 3 was reporting false information or whether Worker 3
had direct information that what Worker 3 was reporting was not
accurate. Department Worker F reported only knowing
Caregiver E was upset after the court hearing; and contacted
her via email in August. Caregiver E reported she had told
Worker 3 she had not kicked Parent C out the doctor’s visit; and
she would get a letter from the doctor showing that.
GAL G recalled Worker 3 reporting in court that Caregiver E
blocked Parent C from a medical appointment. He reported he
has no reason to believe Worker 3 was reporting false
information or knew she was reporting incorrect information.
Document review:
Child A’s case record which showed:
• She was placed in an unlicensed relative placement with
Caregiver E on 1/19/2023.
• Child A’s mother, Parent C is a 16-year-old and resides
with her mother, Grand Mother H.
4

Analysis Based on interviews there is insufficient evidence to support
that Worker 3 gave false testimony in court. Nor that Worker 3
did not have the character, suitability and ability to meet the
needs of children and families served by the agency.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207 Staff responsibilities.
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all the following activities:
(b) Facilitating services and parenting time for children for
purposes of reunification.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The foster care worker had not completed a home visit at the
parental home before allowing visitation to occur in the home. The
home may not be safe for such visits. The home is heated by a
buddy heater. Additionally, the birth mother’s younger brother,
who lives in the home has threatened to kill Child A should Child A
return to the parental home.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant X
On 11/6/2023 I interviewed Complainant X by telephone.
Complainant X affirmed the allegations. Complainant X reported
Caregiver E expressed concern that Worker 3 allowed Child A to
go for unsupervised visits with Parent C, when Worker 3 has
never been at the parental home. Caregiver E reported Worker 3
admitted that in court. Additionally, Caregiver E expressed
concerns about the safety and appropriateness of the parental
home for unsupervised visit for Child A due to the home being
heated by a “buddy type heater” and that it may not have water.
Additionally, Parent C’s home is not adequate for unsupervised
visit due to a teen in the home threatening harm to Child A if Child
A returns to the home.
Administrator 2
On 11/9/2023 I spoke with Administrator 2 about the allegations
by telephone. Administrator 2 reported with the exception of the
alleged complaint of a relative threatening Child A(which she had
no knowledge of), all the reported concerns were explored before.
Administrator 2 reported there has been meetings with the
department related to matters reported by Caregiver E. She
reported Caregiver E has been expressing concerns since the
start of the case with Eagle Village. Administrator 2 reported the
agency has spoken with the caregiver about the concerns. That
5

Supervisor 4 has gone on home visits with Worker 3 so as to
answer Caregiver E’s concerns. The agency offered to have
Caregiver E meet and talk with them about her concerns.
Additionally, the GAL G offered to talk with Caregiver E; and there
have been meetings with Caregiver E along with Department of
Health and Human Services (DHHS) to address Caregiver E’s
concerns. Despite these meetings Caregiver E’s concerns were
not satisfied. Caregiver E has not been completely cooperative, by
refusing to provide medical information to the agency related to
the child.
Administrator 2 reported Parent C’s home is not heated by a
“buddy heater’, the home is heated by propane, and this was
verified by the worker as recent as 11/2/2023. Administrator 2
reported Worker 3 and Supervisor 4 could best address more
details on all the allegations.
Worker 3 & Supervisor 4
On 11/13/2023 I interviewed Worker 3 and Supervisor 4
separately by video conference via TEAMs. Administrator 1 was
also present as a support person during each staff person’s
interview.
Worker 3 reported being the foster care worker for Child A’s case
since its assignment to Eagle Village on 1/19/2023. Worker 3
denied the allegations. Worker 3 reported Child A’s permanency
plan was initially termination of parental rights. A court hearing
was held in April of 2023, and a permanency trial was to occur in
July 2023. Children’s protective services and the court agreed to
take termination of parental rights off table for six months; and the
current permanency plan is reunification with Parent C. Worker 3
reported she has continually worked with Parent C, and Caregiver
E; inclusive of discussing the child’s permanency plan, reviewing
service plans and informing her about the status of the case. She
has also worked with Parent C on court ordered
services/requirements.
Worker 3 denied Caregiver E contacting her about nonreceipt of
any documents. She said Caregiver E complained to DHHS not
Eagle Village. Caregiver E complained to DHHS that Caregiver E
thought Worker 3 was not taking Worker 3’s job seriously.
Caregiver 3 wanted DHHS to take the case back from Eagle
Village.
Worker 3 denied home visits not occurring to Parent C’s home,
which is that of Parent C’s mother’s home. Worker 3 denied the
6

home not being safe for Child A to visit. She said prior to an
8/2/2023 assessment of the parental home, and the court ordering
unsupervised visits for Parent C the third week of October 2023,
weekly visits (sometimes twice weekly visits, if concerns or issues
were reported) occurred. Worker 3 said the home visits included
unannounced home visits. She said at the home visit on 8/2/2023
there had been a concern about no running water. She verified
there is running water. She said there was also no operable
smoke detector; and the floors were not clean. The family was told
to clean the floors and to take care of the smoke detectors and
carbon monoxide devices. At Worker 3’s home visit that occurred
on 10/18/2023, she observed that the floors were clean, and she
checked for batteries in the detector(s). She said a standard
safety plan was completed with the family on 10/23/2023 when the
judge ordered unsupervised home visits for Child A.
Worker 3 reported the parental home has been very warm during
her visits to the home. She reported having no knowledge of
what a buddy heater is. She reported Parent C does have a space
heater in Parent C’s room, which has not been in use during her
home visits.
Worker 3 denied knowledge of any child in the home threatening
to hurt Child A. No such a concern was brought up to her. She
reported Parent C does have two brothers in the home and both
are minors. She said the younger brother is Child B, and he has
some behavior issues. She has observed both Child B and the
older brother in the home, and around Child A. Child B has
behaved well around Child A; and no issues have been observed
or reported for the older brother.
Supervisor 4, like Administrator 2 and Worker 3 also reported
Caregiver E was reporting concerns to DHHS and not reaching
out directly to Eagle Village. Supervisor 4 reported Caregiver E
was apparently contacting Osceola DHHS concerning Eagle
Village’s management of the case. Caregiver E began contacting
the DHHS licensing unit with general management concerns in
May 2023. This ramped up with more specific concerns related to
the parent and the parental home sometime in July 2023, after
DHHS set aside permanent custody as an action it would pursue.
Supervisor 4 reported due to these things happening she began
accompanying Worker 3 to Caregiver E’s home visits for support.
She advised Caregiver E and Caregiver E’s husband when they
have concerns they can contact her; and can also go up the chain
of command if they are not getting their concerns addressed.
Supervisor 4 reported Caregiver E has her and Worker 3’s email
7

address and telephone number; but Caregiver E has never
reached out to her with a specific concern. During Caregiver E’s
attendance at a meeting with DHHS on this case to address the
caregiver’s case management concerns, Caregiver E only asked a
question about the reunification process. That information was
shared with Caregiver E. Supervisor 4 said that information had
also been shared by Worker 3 at Caregiver E’s home visits.
Supervisor 4 reported when Parent C’s case was initially opened
there was concern that Parent C had a space heater and there
was no heat in the home. She affirmed what Administrator 2
reported, that it has been verified during the worker’s home visits
as recent as a November 2023 home visit that the home has an
appropriate heat source.
Supervisor 4 affirmed Worker 3’s reporting that there are two
brothers in the parental home. She said no one ever mentioned a
concern to her about another child in the home threatening to hurt
or harm Child A.
Caregiver E
I interviewed Caregiver E by telephone on 11/17/2023.
Caregiver E reported Parent D is her great nephew. She said
Child A was placed in their unlicensed relative care by DHHS on
12/6/2022 following Child A’s removal from Parent C’s and Parent
D’s custody. She advised that for a brief while they had temporary
guardianship for Child A. She reported since DHHS completed the
placement with them, and was at all court hearing, she thought
DHHS was responsible for Child A’s case. She admitted to
contacting DHHS as opposed to Eagle Village with her concerns
about Parent C and the parental home. She reported she got
confused about who the responsible agency was, so she was
contacting DHHS and sending things to them. She reported later
confusion as she noted DHHS transferred the case to Eagle
Village in January 2023. She said when she started contacting
Worker 3 three to four months ago she was not getting results,
and so she was contacting both DHHS and Eagle Village. She did
not clarify what specifically she had contacted Worker 3 about
which Worker 3 was not giving her results on. I asked Caregiver E
whether she had contacted Supervisor 4 related to concerns or
about any lack of contact from Worker 3. Caregiver E admitted
she had not. She reported she did subsequently contact
Administrator 0. Administrator 0 suggested they have a meeting;
and a meeting was held with DHHS and Eagle Village. Caregiver
8

E reported she is now clear that Eagle Village has case
responsibility for Child A’s case.
As for Worker 3 not making home visits to Parent C’s home,
Caregiver E reported not knowing how it would be possible that
Worker 3 would not have completed a visit to Parent C’s home
prior to Parent C being allowed to have unsupervised visits with
Child A. She just reported knowing Worker 3 said Worker 3 had
not at a court hearing in October 2023. Caregiver E said Child A’s
unsupervised visits started in October 2023. Notwithstanding
Caregiver E reporting that Worker 3 said Worker 3 had not made
home visits; Caregiver E simultaneously reported Worker 3
reported at that hearing that the home needed a smoke detector
and the carbon monoxide detector needed batteries. Caregiver E
did not report taking into account Worker 3’s reports of what
devices were lacking the home likely came by way of a visit to the
home by Worker 3.
As to the allegation of the birth mother’s younger brother was
threatening to kill Child A, Caregiver E reported knowing this
allegation to be true. She reported the threat was made by Parent
C’s six-year-old brother, Child B, who has anger issues. She said
she saw a direct message post by either Parent C or Parent D
mentioning it. She said she told Worker 3 about this matter early
on and Worker 3 said she would take care of it. Later Worker 3
said Child B was getting counseling for his issues. Caregiver E did
not elaborate on when these conversations occurred.
Department Worker F and GAL G
Department Worker F and GAL G were interviewed by me by
telephone on 11/21/2023 and 12/5/2023 respectively. Neither
reported having information about any child in the home
threatening harm to Child A.
Department Worker F reported Eagle Village has case
responsibility; and as such she has not visited the parental home.
She did not recall Worker 3’s description of the parental home, but
questioned whether the condition of the home was minimized. She
based that on her contact with Caregiver E, GAL G and a
11/14/2023 case contact denoting a concern. Notwithstanding
that, at the 10/2023 court hearing, the judge did not indicate a
concern with those environmental barriers. The court ordered the
unsupervised home visits.
GAL G denied the allegations related to the home. He said he has
visited Parent C’s residence, and the home has heat, electricity
9

and had a full inspection. He reported having no knowledge that
the home was not up to code.
Document review:
• Social work contacts of announced and unannounced
home visits to Parent C’s home, which showed information
as reported by Worker 3 related to the home’s condition,
discussions on safety proofing of the home, removing sharp
items, having a baby gate and checking so such; checking
on the home’s heat source/noting the heat source as
propane, checking devices in the home, exploration of a
marijuana concern that had been reported, verifying the
home still had running water; and the worker’s instruction to
the family related to cleaning the home, and the worker
providing support. Unannounced and announced home
visits were documented for 8/2/2023; 10/18/2023,
10/16/2023; 11/7/2023, 11/14/2023; and 11/29/2023. Other
prior visits were documented as 5/11/2023, 3/15/2023,
2/9/2023; 1/31/2023 and 1/26/203 whereby case reviews,
permanency planning discussion occurred and advisement
and encouragement was being indicated.
• A Safety Plan dated 10/23/2023 that showed Parent C
agreed to do things to keep Child A safe in the home.
Parent C will utilize appropriate supervision of Child A at all
time; will be honest and report barriers and safety concerns
to the worker; will not allow others to attend the parenting
times unless approved by the worker beforehand; will keep
the home safe and clean; will use a baby gate if needed;
will put all medicines/chemicals/sharp objects out of reach
of the child; will keep the floors/areas clean and free of
small/non-safe objects; and practice safe sleep .
• An email from Caregiver E of screen shots of what
appeared to be text messages/communications between
Parent D (as well as photos of Child A) and someone (no
name shown.
➢ A couple of messages asked if the house was safe,
clean; and a couple of messages appear to
mention someone needing help. No names were
mentioned.
➢ One text did mention Child B’s name; liking to beat
on little kids; but no mention of Child B or anyone
threatening to hurt Child A.
• A Central Michigan District Health Department (CMDH)
Complaint Investigation Report related to a complaint
received 10/24/2023 and denoting a 11/14/2023
investigation start date.
10

➢ The complaint was from an anonymous source.
➢ It alleged multiple single mobile homes on the
property as well as camper trailers, believed to not
be hooked to a well or septic or electric. A trash
piled six feet high.
➢ The CMDHD complaint indicated the complaint
closed as the structure has functioning sewage
disposal and water supply. Owner, Grand Mother H
reported appointment with the building department
to verify home compliance. Grand Mother H was
advised to clean the debris on the property.
Analysis Based on interviews and case documentations, Worker 3 did
conduct visits to Parent C’s home prior to unsupervised visits and
the home was deemed safe for those visits at the time. There is
insufficient evidence to support the allegations of a lack of effort to
facilitate services and parenting time for reunification.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207 Staff responsibilities.
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all the following activities:
(a) placing and supervising children in out- of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Allegation 1: There are concerns that unsupervised visits are
permitted with an underage parent using marijuana. Additionally,
that the worker admitted in court that she has not received drug
screens on the birth mother in two months.
Allegation 2: The worker allows the birth mom to attend medical
appointments without an approved visitation supervisor present.
Allegation 3: There are numerous campers on the property
where Parent C lives with people living in them; and it is unknown
if background checks were completed before allowing visits at the
residence.
Investigation Allegation 1:
Interviews:
Complainant X
On 11/6/2023 I interviewed Complainant X by telephone.
Complainant X reported it was reported to her by Caregiver E that
Worker 3 is aware that Parent C uses marijuana; and Worker 3 is
believed to be okay with that. Caregiver E further alleged that
11

Worker 3 reported even if Parent C uses marijuana, as long as
there is a sober caregiver in the home with Parent C and Child A,
then it’s acceptable. Caregiver E expressed to her this is not okay
because Parent C is 16 and Parent C using drugs is not legal.
Also, that Parent C was still having “dirty” drug screen drops.
Administrator 2
On 11/9/2023 I spoke with Administrator 2 about the allegations
by telephone. She reported the caregiver’s complaints were
addressed via DHHS. She denied the allegations; and reported
Worker 3 and Supervisor 4 could best address any details about
these allegations.
Worker 3 & Supervisor 4
On 11/13/2023 I interviewed Worker 3 and Supervisor 4
separately by video conference via TEAMs. Administrator 1 was
also present as a support person during each staff person’s
interview.
Worker 3 denied the allegations. She admitted a concern was
reported about Parent C and the parental home. She said,
Caregiver E reported smelling marijuana on 10/26/2023, though
Caregiver E does not go into the home when she transports Child
A to the home. Parent C comes to Caregiver E’s car to retrieve
Child A. Worker 3 reported making a home visit to Parent C’s on
10/26/2023, around 5:20PM. She did not smell marijuana in the
home or on Parent C. She had Parent C complete a drug screen
that day, which was the second drug screen for Parent C that
week. Both screens were negative. Worker 3 admitted Parent C’s
substance issues were with marijuana. Parent C’s is court ordered
to complete assessment and treatment for marijuana, with weekly
random drug screens. Worker 3 also admitted she testified in
court about Parent C’s drug screens, but reported the allegations
as indicated in the complaint were not accurate. She repeated,
that Parent C is screened weekly. She said at that court hearing,
she did not have Parent C’s September drug screen results and
that’s what she reported. She reported she is not okay with Parent
C smoking Marijuana, nor did she report that to Caregiver E or
anyone else. She said she knows, as does Parent C, that Parent
C is not old enough to legally smoke marijuana. That this is why
they conduct drug screens. She reported she only referred to
policy related to a sober caregiver being in the home.
Supervisor 4 reported unsupervised visits for Parent C were
ordered by the court not Eagle Village. The court did not ask
12

whether Eagle Village was supportive of such. Supervisor 4
acknowledged they had no concerns against it at that time.
Supervisor 4 affirmed Worker 3’s reporting of the assessment of
the parental home; though advised another supervisor not her was
involved in the full assessment of the home. She said she
attended each court hearing with Worker 3; and Worker 3 never
reported to the court that Worker 3 never visited Parent C’s home
nor was it accurate that Worker 3 reported she was accepting of
Parent C using marijuana. Supervisor 4 affirmed Worker 3
reported policy and it being technically illegal for Parent C to use
marijuana. Additionally, she reported there is a safety plan in
place related to this. As for the drug screens, Supervisor 4 said
Parent C is screened weekly for drug use. She reported the court
report spoke to the drug screens they had, and Worker 3 reported
in court what test screen results were pending.
Caregiver E
I interviewed Caregiver E by telephone on 11/17/2023. Caregiver
E affirmed the information as reported by the complainant. She
reported hearing Worker 3 say in court that there were no drug
screen results for Parent C for August and September 2023.
Additionally, Worker 3 also indicated there were four other
screens that Parent C did not pass; and Worker 3 reported that it
was okay if Parent C was to smoke marijuana as long as there
was a sober caregiver in the home at the time with Child A.
Caregiver E admitted the judge made no objections nor stated any
concerns related to the agency’s reporting to the court. Caregiver
E reported she is concerned because she wants to make sure
Child A stays safe, because Parent C has used marijuana and is
not innocent as to why Child A came into care. Caregiver E said
Parent D wants Child A to stay with her and her family.
Department Worker F and GAL G
Department Worker F and GAL G were interviewed by me by
telephone on 11/21/2023 and 12/5/2023 respectively.
Department Worker F reported finding it strange that Worker 3 did
not have Parent C’s drug screen results for one month when
usually it should take seven to ten days to get those by going to a
portal; but both she and GAL G affirmed that Worker 3 reported in
court to not have Parent C’s drug screen results for September,
not that these screens were not run or that there were problem
with all of them.
Document review:
13

Child A’s case record showed:
• Documentation of twice weekly unsupervised parent times
in the parental home. Social work contacts were brief, but
no concern indicated about the parenting time.
• Court Report dated 10/14/2023, for a 10/16/2023 court
hearing. This report indicated one May, two June and one
August 2023 positive drug screen for Parent C, and the
other drug screens for June, July and August were all
negative. No September screens were noted.
• A 10/26/2023 social work contact by Worker 3 to Parent C’s
home and documentation shows what she observed and
the drug testing that day of Parent C.
• Documentation of unannounced home visits to the parental
home on 8/2/2023, 10//18/2023, 10/23/2023, 11/7/2023,
and 11/14/2023.
➢ The 8/2/2023 home visit documented the issues
reported by Worker 3 related to safety proofing of
the home, and smoke detector/ carbon monoxide
battery needs. Along with floors needing to be
cleaned.
➢ The 10/18/2023 home visit documented the concern
barriers listed at the 8/2/2023 visit were rectified.
➢ The 10/23/2023 home visit documented a safety
plan for the parent/family was discussed and the
worker advised Parent C no one can be around
Child A without clearances.
➢ The 11/7/2023 home visit documented the worker
discussed a parenting issue related to Child A;
advising Parent C to use bottled water and provided
the family with some bottled water.
➢ The 11/14/2023 home visit documented the
discovery of Caregiver E on the property, as well as
men from a health or environmental authority. It also
documented Early On staff was working with the
child/family.
Allegation 2:
Interviews:
Complainant X
On 11/6/2023 I interviewed Complainant X by telephone.
Complainant X affirmed the allegation information as stated in the
complaint. No additional details were indicated by Complainant X.
Administrator 2
On 11/9/2023 I spoke with Administrator 2 about the allegations
by telephone. Administrator 2 reported the caregiver’s complaints
14

were addressed via DHHS. She reported Worker 3 and
Supervisor 4 could best address this allegation.
Worker 3 & Supervisor 4
On 11/13/2023 I interviewed Worker 3 and Supervisor 4
separately by video conference via TEAMs. Administrator 1 was
also present as a support person during each staff person’s
interview.
Worker 3 reported Parent C is allowed to be aware of and attend
Child A’s medical appointments. There is no court order against
this, and it is permittable with the child’s caregiver present.
Supervisor 4 affirmed Worker 3’s report on this matter.
Caregiver E
I interviewed Caregiver E by telephone on 11/17/2023. Caregiver
E affirmed the information as reported by the complainant. She
reported being concerned about Child A’s safety, and just wanting
the best for Child A. She did not know whether the agency could
allow Parent C to attend medical visits without an agency person
being present.
Document Review:
October 2023 Court order, which indicated:
• Placement and visitation shall be at the discretion of the
Department of Health and Human Services. All other prior
findings and Orders hereby remain in effect.
• On 10/16/2023 that unsupervised parenting time ordered
for Parent C.
Allegation 3:
Interviews:
Complainant X
On 11/6/2023 I interviewed Complainant X by telephone. She
reported Caregiver E is concerned that Parent C’s home is not
adequate for unsupervised visit due to there being numerous
campers on the property where Parent C resides. Caregiver E
has concerns that the person residing in the campers may
possibly be unsuitable to have contact with the child because it is
unknown if background checks were completed before allowing
visits at Parent C’s home.
Administrator 2
On 11/9/2023 I spoke with Administrator 2 about the allegations
by telephone. Administrator 2 denied the allegations. She
15

reported Worker 3 and Supervisor 4 could best address this
allegation.
Worker 3 & Supervisor 3
On 11/13/2023 I interviewed Worker 3 and Supervisor 3
separately by video conference via TEAMs. Administrator 1 was
also present as a support person during each staff person’s
interview.
Worker 3 reported these concerns relates to two people; Person
XX and Person XY, both of whom were cleared by DHHS on
10/18/2023. Worker 3 reported the only time there was multiple
individuals at a visit was at Child A’ s birthday party/celebration
which was supervised at the agency. Worker 3 reported she had
searched MISACWIS to assert there were no hits for them at that
time. She said this matter was addressed with Caregiver E by her
and GAL G at that time.
Supervisor 4 affirmed being aware that Worker 3 had requested
clearances related to some people. She was not sure whether
Worker 3 had obtained them. She reported no other people are
allowed to attend visits in the home.
Caregiver E
I interviewed Caregiver E by telephone on 11/17/2023. Caregiver
E reported that during Child A’s birthday party in July of 2023 at
Eagle Village she was told it would just be immediate family, but
there were about 15 people there. Some of the people had
criminal histories. Caregiver E was not in the visit, she reported
not being allowed in. She left Child A for the visit after a second
staff showed for the visit. She reported knowing the worker did not
conduct clearances on all because she was told the clearances
were ran after that date.
Caregiver E reported knowing at least one guy, whom she
reported knowing has/had a criminal history and a warrant out.
She reported knowing this back then because of her prior section
8 coordinator’s job/role to run clearances and that person was one
she would have conducted a clearance for. She reported being
concerned with the trailer neighborhood and people connected to
where Parent C lives. She wants to make sure the agency is doing
all they should to keep Child A safe.
Department Worker F & GAL G
Department Worker F and GAL G were interviewed by me by
telephone on 11/21/2023 and 12/5/2023 respectively.
16

Department Worker F reported that Caregiver E reported that a
person was moving in or living on the property where Parent C
lives. That this person is on central registry. Department Worker F
said she contacted Worker 3 with that name. Worker 3 did not
know the name and was going to follow up. On 9/8/2023,
Department Worker F reported she ran clearance checks on all
the household members on the property due to Worker 3 not be
able to do all. She said on 10/23/2023 she spoke with Worker 3
about the earlier person. Worker 3 reported no to the person
(believed to be a mentor or neighbor, but no name given) living in
the home. Worker 3 reported advising Parent C that Parent C and
Child A could not be around this person.
GAL G reported with respect to clearances, Parent C met an adult
friend who was going to be a mentor, then that person’s husband
became involved. Eagle Village stopped any visits until they
obtained clearances. DHHS was involved with this process.
Caregiver E found out about this and reported a concern. GAL G
reported having no reason to believe the agency or the worker
was not following protocol related to this matter.
Documentation Review:
• A review of criminal history and child protective clearances
for Person XX and Person XY provided by Worker 3. Which
did not show any hits.
Analysis Based on interviews and case documentations there is insufficient
evidence to support a lack of effort by the agency to work with the
child, the child’s family and other individuals to develop and
implement the service plan.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Continuation of the facility’s current licensing status is recommended.
